It‚Äôs valuable to show rather than tell, so let‚Äôs go over some performance monitoring tools and techniques so that you can learn how to measure the speed of your site and measure your site‚Äôs performance. In particular, I‚Äôll go over two tools: Lighthouse and WebPagetest, and two metrics, Time to Interactive (TTI) and Speed Index. Chrome will simulate a slower, mobile device, and measure the performance of your site on the criteria previously mentioned. Of particular note is the trace, which takes screenshots of your site as it loads. The less blank white screens your users see, the better. The quicker your site loads in this trace, the happier your users will be as your site is
blazing fast and a joy to use.
Maximizing this trace coupled with a concept known as TTI, or Time to Interactive, means that not only does your site load fast, but that it is able to be accessed and actually

quickly too. If your site shell and content loads quickly, but JavaScript and other resources are still blocking the main thread, your users will leave your site and/or grow frustrated! Blazing fast isn‚Äôt just the appearance of loading fast, it‚Äôs loading fast coupled with actually

It‚Äôs also pertinent to discuss Speed Index when discussing performance measurements. Speed Index is
‚Äù‚Ä¶ the average time at which visible parts of the page are displayed.‚Äù

In effect, Speed Index gives us an idea how fast the separate pieces of our page are loaded and filled in. A page that loads disparate elements‚Äîe.g. the header, page content, sidebar, etc.‚Äîmore quickly is a page that gives your user the sense of a fast-loading page. Couple a quick speed index with a blazing time to interactive, and you have a page that not only gives the appearance of loading quickly but one that is also
quickly. This is the gold standard we strive for at Gatsby.
